newsitem.title: JAPAN: Japan oil slick reaches coast.
newsitem.headline: Japan oil slick reaches coast.

text.p: Parts of an oil slick from a sunken Russian tanker started washing ashore in northern Japan on Tuesday, threatening a possible environmental disaster for an area called the Noto Peninsula, a Maritime Safety Agency (MSA) spokesman said.
The spokesman told Reuters the 10-km (six-mile) wide slick had broken into many parts and the first patch washed ashore on a beach at Echizen.

Bad weather has dogged efforts to stop the oil spill since the 13,157-tonne Russian-registered Nakhodka, carrying 19,000 tonnes (133,000 barrels) of heavy fuel oil, sank and broke in two during storms in the Sea of Japan last Thursday.
"It's impossible to mount cleanup operations because of continuing stormy weather," the spokesman said.
It has been estimated that at least 3,700 tonnes (26,000 barrels) of oil had escaped from ruptured tanks in the ship's bow and further oil was leaking from tanks in the stern.
The Noto Peninsula, about 350 km (220 miles) west of Tokyo, is a rich fishing ground famed for its shrimp, crabs and women divers known as "Ama".
